name: Senator Mike Braun
tweet_text: Promising Pathway Act increases innovation in clinical trial design and encourages sponsors to use real world data to ascertain the benefits of the drug without reducing the FDA‚Äôs standard of safety or effectiveness.

name: Senator Mike Braun
tweet_text: Promising Pathway Act requires FDA to use a rolling, priority review pathway to evaluate drugs intended to treat, prevent, or diagnose serious diseases. Provisional approval is granted to drugs demonstrating substantial evidence of safety & early evidence of positive outcomes.

tweet_text: Promising Pathway Act gives people with serious and life-threatening illnesses a fighting chance to receive timely access to innovative treatments in America‚Äîand patients are willing and wanting to take on the challenge. #PassPromisingPathway #FDA #PDUFA

name: Senator Mike Braun

It didn‚Äôt take long to start raising the rates on the lower income brackets. 

By 1916, the rates were 2% for the bottom bracket (those making less than $500,000 in 2021 $) and 25% for the top. 

Now, the lowest tax rate is 10 times higher than it originally was.

name: Senator Mike Braun
tweet_text:
In 1913, the first federal income tax imposed a 1% tax on incomes above $3,000 ($83,000 in 2021 $), with a 6% tax on the highest bracket at $500,000 (~$14,000,000 in 2021 $). 

Democrats at the time argued that this would only affect the rich.

name: Senator Mike Braun

name: Senator Mike Braun
tweet_text:
And for those claiming they're going to pay for this by "taxing the rich":

Even if you taxed the top 40% of earners at 100%, it wouldn't raise enough to cover our yearly deficit.

In other words: Taking every cent the wealthy make wouldn't even get us out of the red.

name: Senator Mike Braun
tweet_text:

name: Senator Mike Braun
tweet_text:
I voted against the Bipartisan Budget Act of 2019 which suspended the debt limit to now, because I refuse to kick the can down the road.

We need real reforms for our budget crisis.

What the Democrats are asking for is a blank check to keep spending us into the poorhouse.

name: Senator Mike Braun
tweet_text:
Republicans & Democrats have both been at fault for our massive national debt and yearly deficits.

I came here from Main Street, where we make budgets and live by them.

That's why I've refused to vote for the massive debt we're shoveling onto our kids and grandkids.

name: Senator Mike Braun
tweet_text:
The debt limit doesn't need to be raised to cover the bipartisan spending in 2020.
 
The Bipartisan Budget Act of 2019 covered all spending from August 2, 2019 to July 31, 2021.
 
Saying the debt ceiling needs to be lifted or suspended to cover Republican debt is inaccurate.

name: Senator Mike Braun
tweet_text:

But the big spending Democrats saw an opportunity.

They added $2 trillion more with President Biden's liberal slush fund this spring, sold to the American people as more "COVID relief."

name: Senator Mike Braun
tweet_text:

There is never enough tax revenue to satisfy Democrats whose growth business is the federal government.

name: Senator Mike Braun
tweet_text:

Even before COVID, Congress routinely spent about 1 trillion dollars more than the government takes in annually.

name: Senator Mike Braun

Some say $3.5 trillion, but that's not counting $263 billion in new discretionary spending, and $390 billion in debt interest.

Some have said it's as high as 5T or 7T.

But we know for sure: it's not $0.

name: Senator Mike Braun
tweet_text:
9. CLAIM: $2.9 billion interest rate smoothing options for defined benefit pension plans

FACT: Interest rate smoothing is a creative accounting gimmick that rears its head in Washington every few years. It was a gimmick then, it's a gimmick now.

name: Senator Mike Braun
tweet_text:
8. CLAIM: $3 billion in savings from reducing Medicare spending on discarded medications

FACT: $2.8 billion is estimate of Medicare drugs thrown away every year due to single use vials.

Setting aside concerns about safety, this dollar amount will certainly not reach $3 billion.

name: Senator Mike Braun
tweet_text:
7. CLAIM: $6 billion in sales from Strategic Petroleum Reserve. 

FACT: 

This is liquidating an asset we previously paid for, and we will have to pay to replace.

name: Senator Mike Braun
tweet_text:
6. CLAIM: $8.7 billion from mandatory sequester. 

FACT: Wishful thinking. These "mandatory" sequesters never get done because D.C. doesn't follow any of our own budget rules.

name: Senator Mike Braun
tweet_text:
5. CLAIM: $56 billion in economic growth

I'm glad CBO is using dynamic scoring to take into account economic effects, which they should have done on the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act. Tax cuts create far more growth in the economy than federal spending.

This is a rosy estimate at best.

name: Senator Mike Braun
tweet_text:
4. CLAIM: $53 billion from states returning unused federal enhanced unemployment benefits. 

FACT: Repurposing unused COVID relief funds we borrowed in the first place is not a real pay-for.

name: Senator Mike Braun
tweet_text:
3. CLAIM: $49 billion in savings from delaying the Medicare Part D rebate rule.

FACT: Raising drug prices on seniors is not a pay-for, it's wrong.

name: Senator Mike Braun
tweet_text:
2. CLAIM: Funding from recouping fraudulent enhanced federal unemployment payments.

FACT: Just like the "tax-gap," estimates for how much fraudulent UI was paid and how much can be recouped is conjecture.

Repurposing money the federal government previously wasted doesn't count.

name: Senator Mike Braun
tweet_text:
1. CLAIM: $205 billion from repurposing unused COVID relief funds. 

FACT: We should be repurposing COVID relief funds, but reshuffling money we borrowed in the first place doesn't count as a pay-for.
